sentence: The Procter & Gamble CompanyPG will sell its Frédéric Fekkai high-end hair care brand and salons as part of its plan to strengthen its portfolio and streamlining the business.
Financial details of the deal have been kept under wraps.
The premium hair care products and salons will be sold to Designer Parfums and LUXE Brands with the transaction likely to close in June.
While Designer Parfums is a private family-owned business dealing in perfumes and beauty products, LUXE Brands is a prestige beauty company.

The two companies will form a joint venture to buy the Fekkai business which comprises a range of hair care products and seven salons in the U.S. All the 255 employees of Fekkai salon operations are expected to be transferred to the new company.
Both Designer Parfums and LUXE Brands are looking to expand in the beauty business which led to the purchase.
The divesture is in line with P&G's portfolio strengthening and simplification plans, announced in August last year.
Under the plan, the company aims to streamline its business to focus more on its biggest brands, including the Billion Dollar Brands like Tide, Pampers and Oral-B.
The company will eliminate (partner, divest or discontinue) 60% of the brands (equating to roughly 100 brands) whose sales and profits have been declining over the past three years.
At the third-quarter conference call held in April this year, P&G management stated that the company has already divested, discontinued or made plans to consolidate over 40 brands.
In keeping with the plan, last year, P&G sold off its American and Asian pet care business to Mars, Inc. in July and the European pet care business to Spectrum Brands Holdings, Inc. SPB in December.
Moreover, the company has signed a deal to divest its Duracell batteries business to Berkshire Hathaway, Inc. BRK.B in exchange for Berkshire's equity stake in P&G.
In addition, the company has exited the Bleach business, Vicks VapoStream, Camay and Zest bar soap brands, and several skin care and fragrance brands.
Camay and Zest soap brands were sold to U.K.-based consumer goods giant Unilever, plc UL in December last year.
Once the divestures are completed, P&G will have a portfolio of about 65 consumer and shopper preferred leading brands that have accounted for 85% of its sales and over 95% of its profits.
We believe that a smaller and more focused company should be able to grow faster, create more value and be much easier to manage.
